publicationStmt.p: This is an XML-TEI markup of the original publications by SIL Mexico for the purposes of: archival and for the creation of a body of Mixtepec-Mixtec language resources (LR) (ISO: mix). Encoded documents used with the permission of original authors.

notesStmt.note: Cuenta la leyenda que hace mucho tiempo no había sol. La oscuridad le daba vida a las piedras. Por eso ellas podían caminar. Un grupo de hombres llevó piedras a Tlaxiaco y construyó una iglesia. Otro grupo de hombres de Mixtepec quiso hacer lo mismo, pero salió el sol y las piedras murieron. Por eso, en esa época, no se pudo construir la iglesia de Mixtepec.

sourceDesc.bibl: Tu'un yata uvi veñu'u Mendoza Santiago, Francisco; Beckmann, Gisela; Nieves, María M.. 2008. (2nd ed.).Instituto Lingüístico de Verano, A.C. Tlalpan, D.F., México Obtained from:

textDesc.channel: @mode:'w' means that the primary means of utilising this document is by reading it's written form;
textDesc.derivation: this document is labeled "original" because the XML-TEI markup of it's contents have not made any alterations to the original content;

normalization.ab: 2018-03-28Spelling of lexical items which in the old orthography were homographs and which have been changed according to updated orthographic principles as per ../Mille/GUIA_ORTOGRAFICA_PRELIMINAR_Short_version.xml. Instances of "ña" still remain to be changed pending consultation with Mille (or other person working on orthography).

list.item: Mixtec content found at following locations: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg/w

English translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span[@xml:lang='en'] the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere a preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

Spanish translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span[@xml:lang='es'] the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalent where a preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

spanGrp.span: I will tell a tale to everyone, to those that want to know the story, (?) what (?) lived in our town.
not inflected? but this isn't gloss form right? which is "tsini" right?
This story is about the two churches of our town.
Este cuento trata de dos iglesias de nuestro pueblo.
what is the "ña-" doing here? Would the meaning be different if it wasn't included.
There was a church in Tlaxiaco, and one that was in this town of Mixtepec.
Había una iglasia en Tlaxiaco, y había una que estaba en este pueblo de Mixtepec.
And when a long time ago the sun did not exist.
Y hace mucho tiempo cuando el sol no existía.
One day the elder inhabitants gathered together and had a discussion, they said that they will make two churches, one in Tlaxiaco, one in Mixtepec.
Un día los habitantes ancianos se reuniron y discutieron, dijeron que van a construir dos iglesias, una en Tlaxiaco, una en Mixtepec.
what is the sense of "tu'u" here?
Let's collect stones, every stone and let's make
And so they collected rocks and they began to make the (?) of the church of Tlaxiaco.
Y entonces coleccionaron piedras y empezaron a hacer (?) de la iglesia de Tlaxiaco.
And the people were old and small, they lived a long time ago....(and big people), the people were tall.
the people were old and small
la gente eran ancianos y pequeños
And they worked and built Tlaxiaco's church, and the people arrived, people that lived here in San Juan Mixtepec, and then the men from Tlaxiaco said:
Y trabajaron y construyeron la iglesia de Tlaxiaco, y la gente llegó, la gente que vivieron aquí en San Juan Mixtepec, y los hombres de Tlaxiaco dijeron:
Now this church of Tlaxiaco is finished, do us a favor and kick it down.
Ahora esta iglesia de Tlaxiaco está acabada, háganos un favor y pateala abajo.
And the men came from the town of Mixtepec, two (?)... the church, and it all fell down, and then they said:
Oh no! you're too strong, you made it fall off.
¡Ay no! eres demasiado fuerte, lo hicieron caerse.
And now you help me make it.
When it's done, then let's go to Mixtepec, we'll make another one so that the church of Tlaxiaco and the church of Mixtepec will be identical.
Cuando está terminada, vamos a Mixtepec, vamos hacer una otra para que la iglesia de Tlaxiaco parece idéntica a la iglesia de Mixtepec.
there are many instances of "ta ntsinu", why is it "ta ntsinui" here? Would it be wrong to use "ta ntsinu"?
the town of San Juan Mixtepec
la cuidad de San Juan Mixtepec
is this translation right? is "ian" inflected 'one' "in"?
look the same (both churches to look the same) "in" 'one' + "nuu" 'face'!
get some other contexts of this phrase if possible
And there they hurried the construction of the church of Tlaxiaco, and then the church of Tlaxiaco was finished, then they said:
Y allí se daron prisa a construir la iglesia de Tlaxiaco, y cuando la iglesia de Tlaxiaco estaba terminada, pues dijeron:
doesn't make sense in this context...
is this a noun or a verb? is to construct "ntuva'a"?
Now we'll collect rock, you guys go to Mixtepec, go (?) mountain, go with(?) stone.
Ahora coleccionamos piedra, ustedes van a Mixtepec, vayan a (?) montaña, vayan con(?) piedras.
And I'll go to (the town of (?)), (the town of (?)) with stone, and gather (?) there, to make the church.
Y yo me voy a (pueblo de (?)), (pueblo de (?)) con piedra, a coleccionar (?) allí, para construir la iglesia.
what other sense of "ñuu" is there other than 'town'? get recording of tone differences!
And so they looked for trees, and they collected stone, they gathered stone then they began to go after(?)
And the rock was alive with them.
Y la piedra estaba vivo con ellos.
them/ (TS) the rock existed with them
They came, and (?)...(?) the men arrived, they came to (placeName), they arrived at a town called (placeName) with the rocks.
Vinieron, y (?)...(?) los hombres vinieron, llegaron (a|de) (?), llegaron a un pueblo llamado (placeName) con las piedras.
what town is this? what does it's name mean?
There were many rocks living there, so many big rocks, lot's of rocks, they were laying there.
Había muchas piedras vivieron allí, tantas piedras grandes, estaban allí.
is this past? (there is "nikuu" right?) or is it talking about the present of the place which is the same?
And the men arrived at Head Mountain, they arrived with the rocks (?) (?) (Toto Utsa).
Y los hombres llegaron a Montaña de Cabeza, llegaron con piedra a (?) (Toto Utsa).
seems like "chi" is used synonymously as "nuu" and "mancha", others...?
llegó a la Montaña de Cabeza
what is this place name? Parts?
what is this "kuu"? 'be able to' or 'be'?
There is where the old rocks lived, (?)/
Allí es donde las piedras vivieron,(?)
is this past tense? what is present of this verb? would you use "ntsi-" + "ntee"?
They arrived there and the sun came out, and they weren't able to build the church of Mixtepec because the rock died.
Llegaron allí y el sol salió, y no pudieron construir la iglesia de Mixtepec porque murieron la piedra.
add to dictionary entry for sun. And add verb 'ntsinu' to dictionary (is this the same as 'finished'? if so add second sense) if not add new entry (Get recordings!)
is this inflected? is this the main lemma?
And they weren't able to follow it into the town.
Y no pudieron seguirla en el pueblo.
That was how the legend about the church of Mixtepec ends.
Este fue come termine la leyenda sobre la iglesia de Mixtepec.
are "nuu naa" part of a phrase?
That was a short story, (?) small old people told to me,
Hoy en día, no (?) nuestro cuento.
should this be "sna'a"? Is this a misprint or a possibly regional variant?
